# Description of DataSchema variable `dintw`

The description of harmonised variable is the following:
  
* Name: `dintw`
* Label: `day of interview`
* Type of variable: `countinous`
* Missings: 
    + `991 = CAPI/interviewer error`
    + `992 = Impute`
    + `993 = Disable to measure`
    + `994 = Not applicable`
    + `995 = Does not answer`
    + `996 = Not attempt/not done`
    + `997 = Refuse`
    + `998 = Do not know`
    + `999 = Missing`


### ALSA - Wave 1 

#### Study-specific variables

The study-specific variable elected to be harmonised is:

* Name: `datew1`
* Label: `Date of Wave1 interview`
    
```{r assign1}
opal.assign.table.tibble(o, 'ALSA_w1_dinter','ALSA.dates_of_interview_w1',
                         variables=list('datew1'), missings = TRUE)
```

```{r local1}
ALSA_w1_dinter <- opal.execute(o,'ALSA_w1_dinter')
ALSA_w1_dinter$dinter <- as.numeric(format(ALSA_w1_dinter$datew1, '%d'))
Categorical_summary(var = ALSA_w1_dinter$dinter, missing_values = NA)
ggplot(ALSA_w1_dinter, aes(x=factor(dinter))) + geom_bar(stat="count", width=0.4, fill="steelblue") + xlab("Day of interview") + ylab("Frequency")
```

#### Harmonisation algorithm
The harmonized variable is the same than the study-specific variable, but the missing values have to be recoded as follows:

* `NA into 999`

R code of the ALGORITHM:

```{r harmo1}
ALSA_ds_w1 <- tibble(id=ALSA_w1_dinter$id)
ALSA_ds_w1$dintw <- car::recode(ALSA_w1_dinter$dinter, "NA=999")
ALSA_ds_w1$dintw <- labelled(ALSA_ds_w1$dintw, labels = c("Missing"=999, "Do not know"=998, "Refuse"=997, "Not attempt not done"=996, "Does not answer"=995,  "Not applicable"=994, "Disable to measure"=993, "Impute"=992, "CAPI interviewer error"=991))
```

#### Statistics of the new harmonised variable
```{r descript1}
Continuous_summary(var = ALSA_ds_w1$dintw, missing_values = c(991, 992, 993, 994, 995, 996, 997, 998, 999))
ggplot(ALSA_ds_w1, aes(dintw)) + geom_histogram(stat="count", fill="steelblue") + xlab("Year of birth") + ylab("Frequency") + xlim(1,31)
```

#### Validation
```{r crosstabulation1}
BeforeH <- table(ALSA_w1_dinter$dinter, useNA = "ifany")
AfterH <- table(ALSA_ds_w1$dintw)
C <- rbind(BeforeH,AfterH)
colnames(C) <- c(names(AfterH)[1:31])
C
```

### ALSA - Wave 3 

#### Study-specific variables

The study-specific variable elected to be harmonised is:

* Name: `datew3`
* Label: `Date of Wave3 interview`



```{r assign3}
opal.assign.table.tibble(o, 'ALSA_w3_dinter','ALSA.dates_of_interview_w3',
                         variables=list('datew3'), missings = TRUE)
opal.assign.table.tibble(o, 'ALSA_w3_id','ALSA.ALSA-Wave3',
                         variables=list('SEXW3'), missings = TRUE)
```

```{r local3}
ALSA_w3_dinter <- opal.execute(o,'ALSA_w3_dinter')
ALSA_w3_dinter$dinter <- format(ALSA_w3_dinter$datew3, '%d')
ALSA_w3_id <- opal.execute(o,'ALSA_w3_id')

Add_indiv <- function(old, new){
  
  new_2 <- matrix(NA, nrow = dim(new)[1], ncol=dim(old)[2])
  oldm <- as.matrix(old)
  
  for(i in 1:length(new$id)){
    if(sum(new$id[i]==old$id)>=1){
      new_2[i,] <- oldm[which(new$id[i]==old$id),]
    } else {
      new_2[i,] <- c(new$id[i], NA, NA)
    }
  }
  
  new_22 <- data.frame(id=new_2[,1], datew3=new_2[,2], dinter=as.numeric(new_2[,3]))
  new_22
}

ALSA_w3_dinter2 <- Add_indiv(old = ALSA_w3_dinter, new = ALSA_w3_id)


Continuous_summary(var = ALSA_w3_dinter2$dinter, missing_values = NA)
ggplot(ALSA_w3_dinter2, aes(x=factor(dinter))) + geom_bar(stat="count", width=0.4, fill="steelblue") + xlab("Year of interview") + ylab("Frequency")
```

#### Harmonisation algorithm
The harmonized variable is the same than the study-specific variable, but the missing values have to be recoded as follows:

### ALSA - Wave 4 

#### Study-specific variables

The study-specific variable elected to be harmonised is:

* Name: `DATEW4`
* Label: `DATE OF INTERVIEW`
    
```{r assign4}
opal.assign.table.tibble(o, 'ALSA_w4_dinter','ALSA.ALSA-Wave4',
                         variables=list('DATEW4'), missings = TRUE)
```

```{r local4}
ALSA_w4_dinter <- opal.execute(o,'ALSA_w4_dinter')
Date_of_birth <- function(date){
  n <- length(date)
  D <- matrix(NA, nrow = n, ncol = 3)
  for(i in 1:n){
      D[i,] <- as.numeric(t(sapply(date[i], 
                                               function(x) substring(x, first=c(1, 4, 7), 
                                                                     last=c(2, 5, 8)))))
    }
  colnames(D) <- c("Day", "Month", "Year")
  D
}

ALSA_w4_dinter <- cbind(ALSA_w4_dinter, Date_of_birth(ALSA_w4_dinter$DATEW4))

Continuous_summary(var = ALSA_w4_dinter$Day, missing_values = NA)
ggplot(ALSA_w4_dinter, aes(Day)) + geom_histogram(stat="count", fill="steelblue") + xlab("Day of birth") + ylab("Frequency")
```

The harmonized variable is the same than the study-specific variable, but the missing values have to be recoded as follows:

```{r local7}
Add_indiv <- function(old, new){
  
  new_2 <- matrix(NA, nrow = dim(new)[1], ncol=dim(old)[2])
  oldm <- as.matrix(old)
  
  for(i in 1:length(new$id)){
    if(sum(new$id[i]==old$id)>=1){
      new_2[i,] <- oldm[which(new$id[i]==old$id),]
    } else {
      new_2[i,] <- c(new$id[i], rep(NA,2))
    }
  }
  
  new_22 <- data.frame(id=new_2[,1], BIRTHDAT=new_2[,2], dinter=as.numeric(new_2[,3]))
  new_22
}
```

### ALSA - Wave 8 

#### Study-specific variables

The study-specific variable elected to be harmonised is:

* Name: `Date`
* Label: `Date`
    
```{r assign8}
opal.assign.table.tibble(o, 'ALSA_w8_dinter','ALSA.ALSA-Wave8',
                         variables=list('Date'), missings = TRUE)
```

```{r local8}
ALSA_w8_dinter <- opal.execute(o,'ALSA_w8_dinter')

#This function return a table with the date of birth separated by columns:
Date_of_birth <- function(date){
  date <- as.numeric(date)
  n <- length(date)
  D <- matrix(NA, nrow = n, ncol = 3)
  for(i in 1:n){
    if(log10(date[i])+1>=8){
      D[i,] <- as.numeric(t(sapply(date[i], 
                                               function(x) substring(x, first=c(1, 5, 7), 
                                                                     last=c(4, 6, 8)))))
    }
    else{
      D[i,] <- as.numeric(t(sapply(date[i], 
                                               function(x) substring(x, first=c(1, 5, 7), 
                                                                     last=c(4, 6, 8)))))
    }
  }
  colnames(D) <- c("Year", "Month", "Day")
  D
}

ALSA_w8_dinter2 <- cbind(ALSA_w8_dinter, Date_of_birth(ALSA_w8_dinter$Date))
Continuous_summary(var = ALSA_w8_dinter2$Day, missing_values = NA)
```

### ALSA - Wave 9 

#### Study-specific variables

The study-specific variable elected to be harmonised is:

* Name: `DATEW9`
* Label: `Date of interview Wave 9`

    
```{r assign9}
opal.assign.table.tibble(o, 'ALSA_w9_dinter','ALSA.ALSA-Wave9',
                         variables=list('DATEW9'), missings = TRUE)
```

```{r local9}
ALSA_w9_dinter <- opal.execute(o,'ALSA_w9_dinter')

#This function return a table with the date of birth separated by columns:
Date_of_birth <- function(date){
  date <- as.numeric(date)
  n <- length(date)
  D <- matrix(NA, nrow = n, ncol = 3)
  for(i in 1:n){
    if(is.na(date[i])){
      D[i,] <- rep(NA,3)
    }
    else{
      D[i,] <- as.numeric(t(sapply(date[i], 
                                               function(x) substring(x, first=c(1, 5, 7), 
                                                                     last=c(4, 6, 8)))))
    } 
  }
 colnames(D) <- c("Year", "Month", "Day")    
 D
}
```
